title: To the dev who reverted the nunu changes
body: I will make your hell slow, counter jungled, and frozen cold.

replies.body: Just so you know the 'dev who reverted the Nunu changes' is also the dev who's 'still trying to find the right buffs for Nunu and get the rest of the team onboard with them'.
Would that also apply to the Kindred changes we have been seeing on the PBE for the last few patches?
Kind of. That one's less a discussion on what changes we should do and more an ongoing discussion on where Kindred's current power level actually lies.

You folks may not have large plans for Kindred, but I hope you still manage to read this.

**===General===**
I'd very much like to see Kindred function more as a co-operative unit rather than Lamb doing 90% of the work and Wolf showing up to say "hi" every now and then. Additionally, I think Kindred is currently far too reliant on stacks from their passive. I think they would be much easier to balance (and satisfying to play) if some their power was shifted towards item purchases instead.

On that same note, it would be nice to have a clearer idea of what I _should_ buy while playing Kindred. It's nice that they can build pretty much anything, but I sometimes find myself saying "oh god, what _do_ I buy here".

**===Q===**
I don't really have any complaints about how Dance of Arrows works. It's good utility, especially when combined with W, though (again) you may fall behind on your Marks and be stuck with no actual scaling for the rest of the game.

**===W===**
I've tried everything in my power to make Kindred's W an impactful spell, but I just can't do it. To reach 2.5 attack speed (which translates to 1.25 for Wolf), you sacrifice all meaningful damage. Building full AD makes each of Wolf's individual attacks _almost_ relevant, but it hinders Lamb's desire to fire rapid auto-attacks and makes her insanely squishy. The only other source of damage is from Mark of the Kindred, which can be a very unreliable source of power.

I'm not entirely sure what to do with this ability, but I'd like to see Wolf attack faster, more often, and deal more damage. Perhaps you could decrease his scaling from Mark of the Kindred (40% > 10% or 20%?), but allow him to apply on-hit effects or something. With it's current functionality though, it never feels like it's doing anything.

**===E===**
In my opinion, Mounting Dread should be renamed to "Mounting Frustration". The skill is as feast or famine as it gets, you either land the 3 stacks and deal a decent amount of damage _or the skill achieves **absolutely nothing**_ (aside from a very brief slow). I usually find it very difficult to secure that third hit on a marked target, which makes the skill feel like a waste of mana in most cases. The fact that Kindred generally wants bruiser items rather than attack speed is the primary cause of this.

I would very much like to see Wolf contribute to Mounting Dread in a more meaningful way. Some ideas include allowing him to:

-contribute to the 3 stack effect (increase the total stack requirement by 1 or 2 to compensate)
OR
-prioritize targets marked by Mounting Dread while W is active, dealing a small amount of % max health damage on each attack
OR
-make Wolf attack on each added stack, dealing more damage on each subsequent attack, with the final one dealing the full % max health value

**===R===**
As with Q, I don't have many complains about Lamb's Respite. I'm still pretty bad at timing it properly, but that's due to lack of practice. I guess the only thing I can mention is that it can be extremely impactful for the wrong reasons, the AoE generally becomes a horribly-messy street fight where it can be hard to keep track of everything because of how clumped up everyone is. It's like fighting a J4 ult, but everyone **_wants_** to be in it.

====W====

You are missing the mark. The power budget of this skill is in the "jump zone" it creates. 
I.E. the skill tool-tip should read:
- mark an area on the map.
- within this area the CD on Q is nothing.
- also deals RNG damage, prioritized towards your AA target. 

(it actually deals quite a bit of damage i think, but it does not "feel" like a damaging ability)

===E===

spot on, i think.

At somewhere around 20 Marks, Wolf will deal roughly 300 damage per attack while W is active. It takes about 30+ minutes of _continually_ farming bots to get to that point though, so it's a very unrealistic power point to reach in an actual game.

And, like you said, W is more of a "scare" zone than anything else, but I honestly can't say that the area denial makes it a satisfying ability. If Wolf was an _actual_ threat, then I might think otherwise.

W is not a "scare zone" it does major damage but you're not identifying where the damage is coming from.

the damage is coming from Q. 

the base CD on Q is 9. Inside W, 2. that means using W gets 4 casts of Q per W in optimal use case. 

that is a good amount of damage.

You act like I don't know how Kindred works. I'm well aware that Q's cooldown is decreased while W is active, but that doesn't mean that W deals more damage, _it means you get to deal more Q damage_.

And, W doesn't deal "major damage". W deals 25 / 30 / 35 / 40 / 45 (+ 40% AD) damage which, as I said, is pitiful unless you either A) go full AD _which decreases your overall effectiveness_ or B) have an unrealistic number of passive stacks.

I challenge you to make a build that specifically lets Wolf deal respectable damage as well as attack fast enough to make use of it. Literally all you have to work with is total AD, attack speed (which is _half-effective_ for Wolf), and passive stacks.
Then would it be a bad idea to give Kindred 50 extra range on her autoattacks(making it 550)? Just curious.

Kindred seems like one of those champions that's very powerful, but narrow. 

Build them wrong, skill the wrong abilities, or use the wrong runes/masteries, and their narrow margins kick in and they under perform.

Their gameplay seems very rigid and like it punishes deviation very hard.

Where do you think Kindred's power level really is?

Her win rate just spiked, her play rate is pretty low, and her win curve suggests she's one of the hard to learn champs.  Making things harder to judge, her damage output is lower than a bot ADC being played in the jungle but she has a lot of good matchups according to champion.gg.

I'd like to mention a few things...

1)  The nerf to his E a while back took the champion from nitch to straight up depressing to play. Your E was a 3 second slow. If you are unwilling to revert the duration nerf can we please have the AS slow increase with level? That would be one of the best possible buffs which furthers his identity. 

2)  I'd really like to see the buff for eating monsters to scale based on either Q rank or R rank. 1% damage on autos at level 16 is not so great. This would further solidify his control style.  

3)  Can we make his absolute zero start as big as it is now or 90% and make it expand a fair bit like anivia?  Again this emphasizes his zone control which again furthers his identity as a control jg.

I'd love any reasonable change to nunu. The biggest problem I had was when his E changed he became markedly worse and it felt like a nerf which made him clunky to play since you cannot engage with RG or flash snowball any more.
